newsitem.title: THAILAND: Thai March inflation higher than expected.
newsitem.headline: Thai March inflation higher than expected.

text.p: Thailand's annual inflation rate rose 4.5 percent in March, partly driven up by price increases for rice and tap water, the commerce ministry said on Tuesday.
The rise in the consumer price index was above economists' expectations for a 4.1-4.3 percent increase, but the news failed to stir local financial markets, brokers and analysts said.
March consumer prices compared with CPI rises of 4.3 percent in both February and January, the ministry said.
But the latest snapshop of Thai inflation appeared far more benign than last year's performance, when the annual CPI rate ran at a lofty 7.3 percent.
Prices for both food and non-food products rose 0.5 percent month-on-month in March, against an average 0.2 percent increase for the same month in the past 10 years, it added.

"The figure is quite higher than what I predicted. Under the current sluggish economy in which purchasing power is weak, I would have expected prices to remain pretty mild," Vuth Puthamon of Multi-Credit Corp of Thailand told Reuters.
A hike in tap water prices in the Bangkok metropolitan area last month likely contributed to the higher consumer prices, the ministry said.

"The March figure was slightly higher than expected...but it is not that bad. I think overall 1997 inflation could still be restrained to a 4.0-4.5 percent range," said a foreign analyst who declined to be named.
Thailand's 1996 annual inflation rate stood at 5.9 percent.

Analysts did not expect March inflation to further hurt the bearish Thai stock market which has been hammered by a string of negative news in the past year due to a slowing Thai economy, depressed property sector and turmoil in the financial industry.

"It would probably not affect stocks which have come off quite a bit because of Wall Street," the foreign analyst said, adding that investors currently focused more on Thai current account and trade deficits than inflation.

Vuth of Multi-Credit said consumer prices would accelerate in April and May due to seasonal factors. The Thai summer usually pushes up food costs and the re-opening of schools in mid-May spurs education spending.
